storyline.title: Arab Spring
storyline.summary: In December 2010, a young Tunisian set himself on fire after police confiscated his unlicensed cart and wares. This desperate act of rebellion sparked a wave of unrest across the Arab world.

pages.title: Tunisia
pages.summary: Overthrow of Zine El Abidine Ben Ali; Ben Ali flees into exile in Saudi Arabia.

quote.quote: We had a clean revolution. The former president turned out to be a coward. He just ran away. Not like the others - like the poor Libyans, or in Syria - but it lit the fuse to all the other revolutions

pages.title: Demonstrations
pages.summary:
A series of increasingly violent street demonstrations through December.

Thousands of opposition supporters have marched in Tunisia's capital Tunis, demanding the immediate resignation of the Islamist-led government.

The protesters formed a 3km-long (two miles) human chain from the parliament building to the seat of the government.

The rally was a culmination of a week of opposition protests.

Talks between the opposition and the ruling coalition led by the moderate Islamist Ennahda party have so far failed to achieve a major breakthrough.

pages.title: Suicide protestor dies
pages.summary: Mohammed Bouazizi, a Tunisian graduate whose attempted suicide set off violent protests over unemployment across the North Africa nation has died.

person.name: Mohammed Bouazizi
person.summary: Mohamed Bouazizi has become a hero in Tunisia ever since he doused himself in petrol and set himself alight in December, triggering protests which ultimately led to the downfall of President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali.

pages.title: Ousting of president
pages.summary: Ben Ali fled into exile in Saudi Arabia, ending his 23 years in power. A state of emergency was declared and a caretaker coalition government was created.

person.name: Zine El Abidine Ben Ali
person.summary: Led Tunisia for 23 years before stepping down in January 2011 amid an unprecedented wave of street protests.

pages.title: Government resuffle
pages.summary: As a result of continued daily protests, Prime Minister Mohamed Ghannouchi reshuffled the government, removing all former RCD members other than himself.

person.name: Mohamed Ghannouchi
person.summary: The former Prime Minister of Tunisia and was self-proclaimed acting President of the country for a few hours starting 14 January 2011, under Article 56 of the Constitution of Tunisia.

pages.title: Egypt
pages.summary: Inspired by the uprising in Tunisia and prior to his entry as a central figure in Egyptian politics, potential presidential candidate Mohamed ElBaradei warned of a "Tunisia-style explosion" in Egypt.

quote.quote: Our country's condition was getting worse and worse. There was corruption, torture, injustice, inequality and no freedom. Someone had to stand up and say 'enough is enough'

pages.title: Protests
pages.summary: Protests in Egypt began on 25 January 2011 and ran for 18 days. Beginning around midnight on 28 January, the Egyptian government attempted, somewhat successfully, to eliminate the nation's Internet access, in order to inhibit the protesters' ability use media activism to organize through social media.[192] Later that day, as tens of thousands protested on the streets of Egypt's major cities, President Hosni Mubarak dismissed his government, later appointing a new cabinet. Mubarak also appointed the first Vice President in almost 30 years.

pages.title: Square seized
pages.summary: As protests spread to and across Egypt, demonstrators in Cairo took control of central Tahrir Square after a day of hard fighting with police. It was a huge challenge to the regime of President Hosni Mubarak, who at first refused to quit. However, after protesters marched on the Presidential Palace, he finally agreed to step aside on 12 February.

pages.title: Libya
pages.summary: The Libyan Civil War, also referred to as the Libyan Revolution was a 2011 armed conflict in the North African country of Libya, fought between forces loyal to Colonel Muammar Gaddafi and those seeking to oust his government.

quote.quote: It's freedom. There's no Gaddafi, unbelievable. I feel the freedom. I smell the freedom.

pages.title: Protests
pages.summary: Protests in Egypt began on 25 January 2011 and ran for 18 days. Beginning around midnight on 28 January, the Egyptian government attempted, somewhat successfully, to eliminate the nation's Internet access, in order to inhibit the protesters' ability use media activism to organize through social media.[192] Later that day, as tens of thousands protested on the streets of Egypt's major cities, President Hosni Mubarak dismissed his government, later appointing a new cabinet. Mubarak also appointed the first Vice President in almost 30 years.

pages.title: Gaddafi killed
pages.summary: Libya's ex-leader Col Muammar Gaddafi has been killed after an assault on his birthplace of Sirte, officials say. Acting Prime Minister Mahmoud Jibril announced the death, and later said the colonel had been killed in a crossfire between Gaddafi loyalists and fighters from the transitional authorities.

quote.quote: My master is here ... Muammar Gaddafi is here and he is wounded
It's freedom. There's no Gaddafi, unbelievable. I feel the freedom. I smell the freedom.
It's freedom. There's no Gaddafi, unbelievable. I feel the freedom. I smell the freedom.
